Scheme 1 Scheme 2 The CO oxidation mechanism on Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA system proposed by our DFT calculation in the present paper. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Structural formula of Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA SACs and the calculated interaction energy of isolated single Rh3+ atom and PTA/PMA support. Highlighting separation of total interaction energy (E tot) into electrostatic interaction (E es) and bonding interaction (E b) in terms of the unique clathrate structure of PTA and PMA supports and the rectangular pyramid coordination sphere of the Rh atom. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The key geometric parameters of Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs (bond length in Å and bond angle in degree), showing activation of Ob and Oc atom via anchoring effects of Rh atom. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Comparison of the frontier molecular orbitals of Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA SACs. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Optimization stable configurations and calculated adsorption energies (in kcal/mol) for adsorption CO molecules on Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs. Fig 4 Fig. 5 The calculated free energy profiles (in kcal/mol) for oxidation of the first CO molecule by surface Ob (red color) or Oc (blue color) atoms of PMA support. Fig5 Fig. 6 The calculated free energy profiles (in kcal/mol) for oxidation of the second CO molecule by surface Oc atom (red color) of PMA support or O2 (blue color). Fig 6 Fig. 7 The calculated free energy profiles (in kcal/mol) for oxidation of the third CO by adsorbed O2 molecule. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Comparison of the whole free energy profiles (in kcal/mol) for CO oxidation catalyzed by Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs. Fig 8 Fig. 9 The proposed catalytic cycle for CO oxidation via a Rh-assisted Mar-van Krevelen mechanism. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Charge (q, |e|) variation of the Rh atom during CO oxidation catalyzed by Rh1/PTA (red color) and Rh1/PMA (black color) SACs along their favorable reaction pathways. Fig 10 Mars–van Krevelen mechanism for CO oxidation on the polyoxometalates-supported Rh single-atom catalysts: An insight from density functional theory calculations Chun-Hong Lin Conceptualization Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation a Zi-Yi Sun Visualization Formal analysis b Chun-Guang Liu Conceptualization Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing b ⁎ a College of Chemical Engineering, Northeast Electric Power University, Jilin City, 132012, PR China College of Chemical Engineering Northeast Electric Power University Jilin City 132012 PR China bCollege of Chemical Engineering, Northeast Electric Power University, Jilin City, 132012, PR China b Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Beihua University, Jilin City, 132013, PR China Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science Beihua University Jilin City 132013 PR China aDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Beihua University, Jilin City, 132013, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. The low and insufficient anchored site on support structure is the bottleneck problem for development of single-atom catalysts (SACs). Owing to the discrete anionic structure, the surface structure of unimolecular polyoxometalates (POMs) in solid is more like the fragments of metal oxide and possesses the unique separate structure, which can be viewed as the separate small “island” and effectively prevent agglomeration of single metal atoms. In the present paper, the mechanism of CO oxidation by O2 was systematically studied over two POM-supported SACs, Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA (PTA = [PW12O40]3− and PMA = [PMo12O40]3−) by means of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The results indicated that this process involves consecutive oxidation of three CO molecules over Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA SACs via a Rh-assisted Mar-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. The first CO molecule was oxidized by a bridged O atom of POM support to form CO2 molecule and an oxygen vacancy. The surface oxygen vacancy was refilled by O2 molecule, and the second CO molecule was oxidized by a corner O atom of the POM support to form CO2 molecule and a new oxygen vacancy. Finally, the forming surface oxygen vacancy was replenished by the O2 molecule to form the key Mo-O-O-Mo unit, which can easily oxidize the third CO to form the CO2 molecule. Compared with the reported MvK mechanism, the significant difference arises from oxidation of the second CO molecule, in which the second CO molecule was oxidized by the corner O atom of the POM support rather than adsorbed O2 molecule. This is mainly due to a low reactivity for the adsorbed O2 molecule, which comes from a bonding interaction between the adsorbed O2 molecule and the single Rh atom. The atomic charge analysis show that the single Rh atom stabilized on the POM supports promotes the whole catalytic cycle via the change of oxidation state among III, II, and I. All these results show that the presence of single Rh atom on the unimolecular PTA and PMA supports is a key factor for determination of new reaction pathway and high reactivity. We hope our computation results can provide new physical insights to design SACs for CO oxidation by using unimolecular POM cluster. The reaction mechanism of CO oxidation by O2 was systematically studied over two polyoxometalate-supported single-atom catalysts by means of density functional theory calculations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single–atom catalysts Polyoxometalates CO oxidation Mar-van Krevelen mechanism Density functional theory 1 Introduction Single-atom catalysts (SACs), metal atoms are atomically dispersed on the supports [1-6], which can greatly reduce the noble metals consumption and maximize the atom efficiency (100 %), have unique reactivity and selectivity in various energy- and environment-related chemical operations [7-15]. During synthetic procedures and catalytic reaction, however, the isolated single metal atom tends to agglomeration to form cluster, sub-nanoparticle, and nanoparticle on the support surface because of the very high surface energy [16-18]. Although various synthetic strategies, such as high-temperature vapor transport method, photochemical synthetic approach, and self-assembly method, etc., have been developed to improve the sintering-resistant behavior of SACs, reducing the metal loading to a very low level is still a common strategy to avoid agglomeration in preparation of SACs [19-23]. Obviously, this synthesis strategy would significantly decrease active site of SACs. To date, the low and insufficient anchored site on support structure is still the bottleneck problem for development of SACs. The surface chemistry of polyoxometalates (POMs) [24-30] has attracted considerable attentions in the half a century because of their potential applications in the fields of catalysis, corrosion protection of metal, functionalization of metal electrode, metal colloid stabilization, and electroless deposition, etc [31-34]. Differing from the periodic network structure of metal oxides [35], POMs are unimolecular metal-oxo cluster and possesses discrete anionic structure [36-40]. The surface structure of POMs at solid-gas, solid-solid, and solid-liquid interfaces is more like the fragment of metal oxide and can be viewed as the separate small “island” [41-44]. Recently, this surface “island” effects of POMs in interfaces have been cleverly used to prevent agglomeration of single metal atoms and improve sintering-resistant performance of SACs. A series of POM-supported SACs with considerable metal loading and high thermal stability have been successfully synthesized and characterized by Yan group [45-48]. In 2016, they firstly fabricated stable POM-supported SAC with a high Pt loading (close to 1%) on Keggin-type phosphomolybdic acid (PMA)-modified active carbon via anchoring of the single Pt atom on the 4-fold hollow site of PMA surface [49]. They further found that Pt1/PMA SAC displays excellent activity for hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and cyclohexanone. In another case, Yan group successfully dispersed single Rh atom onto the surface of Keggin-type phosphotungstic acid (PTA) with one-to-one manner through a self-assembly method [50]. The reported Rh1/PTA SAC was proved to exhibit high activity for CO oxidation with a moderate apparent activation energy. After three catalytic cycles, it well maintains the complete Keggin-type PTA structure as well as the single atom identity of Rh (atomically dispersed) at the temperature from 50 to 400°C, indicating the excellent sintering-resistant behavior. CO oxidation, as a valuable model reaction in catalytic science [51-64], was further investigated by the same group in another case [65], using an effective combination of experimental and computational technologies. According to operando/in situ spectroscopic experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, they proposed an unconventional Mar-van Krevelen (MvK) pathway for CO oxidation catalyzed by PTA and PMA-supported SACs, which can be roughly divided into the following four steps Scheme 1: This MvK mechanism involves oxidation of CO by surface oxygen atom of PTA/PMA support to form the first CO2 molecule and another CO molecule is adsorbed on the Rh atom subsequently (step 1). Then the surface oxygen vacancy of catalyst was replenished by the O2 (step 2). The second CO react with O2 (step 3) and restore the catalyst surface (step 4). Although the proposed reaction mechanism provided some understandings for CO oxidation, the mechanistic details have not been well studied in details both experimentally and theoretically. Such as, the surface oxygen atoms of Keggin-type POMs can be divided into three sets according to whether they are in terminal (Ot), bridging two metal atoms (Ob), and at the corners (Oc) of the metal-oxo cage. These surface oxygen atoms should possess remarkable difference in reactivity because of different chemical environments [66, 67]. However, they have been indiscriminately treated in exploration of the reaction mechanism. In the present paper, DFT calculations have been carried out to probe the reaction mechanism of CO oxidation catalyzed by Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs. Our findings provide a Rh-assisted MvK reaction pathway, which has been summarized in the following five steps Scheme 2: The proposed MvK mechanism by our DFT calculations contains the adsorbed CO molecule was oxidized by the surface Ob atom to form the first CO2 molecule and an oxygen vacancy on the surface of POM support (step 1). And the first surface oxygen vacancy was refilled by O2 molecule (step 2). Owing to the very high free energy barrier, CO cannot be oxidized by the adsorbed O2 molecule. Alternatively, CO was oxidized by the surface Oc atom to form the second CO2 molecule and a new oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface (step 5). Next, the forming surface oxygen vacancy was replenished by the O2 molecule (step 6) and adsorbed another CO (step 7) to form the key Mo-O-O-Mo unit, which can easily oxidize CO to form the third CO2 molecule (step 8). Finally, the catalytic cycle was formed by reiterating steps 5, 6, 7 and 8. The electronic structural analysis revealed that the oxidation state of the Rh center changes among III, II, and I to promote electron transfer and the whole reaction. We hope these new understandings for the Rh-MvK mechanism can guide the search and preparation of more efficient catalyst for CO oxidation by using POM-supported SACs. 2 Computational details All of the DFT calculations were carried out using Gaussian 09 Revision D.01 software package [68] with M06L functional [69]. M06L functional was designed to involve spin kinetic energy density in a balanced way in the exchange and correlation functionals. Moreover, it was set to meet the uniform-electron-gas limit and is self-correlation-free. M06L functional has been found to be effective for large–sized systems due to the computational advantages of local functionals. Previous theoretical studies have demonstrated that the excellent performance of GGA/M06L functional in thermochemistry, thermochemical kinetics, noncovalent interaction and vibration frequency calculations of main group and transition metal element. Furthermore, the advantages of M06L functional in calculating the geometry, vibration frequency, kinetics, thermochemistry and other aspects of POMs have been confirmed by our previous research [66, 67, 70, 71]. Because the structures obtained via M06L functional are prone to virtual frequency and non-convergence, the quality of the integration grids has been improved to consist with the Gaussian 16. Geometry optimizations were performed by using the standard 6-31G(d) basis set for main group elements and LANL2DZ pseudopotential basis for the all metal elements studied here [72-74]. Any restriction on the symmetry has not been involved in optimization calculations. All the optimized configurations of minima or transition state on the potential energy surface have been checked by the vibration frequency calculations and confirmed by the correct imaginary frequency number at the same level. Imaginary frequency number of the transition state involved in the potential energy surface has been given is Table S1. Moreover, the accuracy of virtual vibration mode of transition state is guaranteed by intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations. Based on the optimized molecule geometries, a single point energy calculation was performed to further refine electronic energy by using the same functional with the polarization and diffusion basis sets 6-31+G(d) for main group atoms and the relativistic energy consistent pseudopotential basis set SDD for transition metal atoms. For the purpose of getting atom charges and Wiberg bond indices (WBI), we performed the natural bond orbital (NBO) analysis [75] with the same functional at the same level (the 6-31G(d) basis for main group elements and LANL2DZ basis sets on the metal atom). Different from the periodic network structure of metal oxides, POMs are a unique class of metal-oxide molecular clusters and bears an isolated and compact anionic structure. Among the POMs family, Keggin-type POMs have been widely researched in experiment and theoretical calculation methond, for which posses considerable stability, well-defined structures. The POMS used in our present work have been characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction. Because many previous works have proved that Rh was anchored at 4-fold hollow site of POMs [49, 50, 65-67, 70, 71], the Rh atom was placed at 4-fold hollows site of POMs manually as the initial structure and then optimized at 6-31g(d) basis (for main group elements) and LANL2DZ basis (sets on the metal atom ). When the optimization process converges and is completed, the structure coordinates are extracted as the SACs model. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Metal-Support Interaction Interaction between single metal atom and supporting matrix significantly influences the catalytic performance of SACs via anchor site, charge transfer, chemical bonding, etc. These factors are often stuck with each other and work together on the catalytic activation. In the present paper, we firstly calculated the interaction energy of isolated single Rh atom and PTA/PMA support. The structural formula of Rh1/PTA (Rh1/PMA) has been listed in Fig. 1 . Yan and co-workers have proven that the single Rh3+ cation was anchored onto the surface of Keggin-type PMA/PTA anion by one-to-one manner [50, 65]. Because Keggin-type PMA/PTA anion possesses clathrate structure, in which the negatively charged PO4 3− unit was embedded into the neutral Mo12O36/W12O36 cage [76-78], the single Rh3+ cation was strongly anchored onto the neutral Mo12O36/W12O36 cage via electrostatic attraction. On the other hand, the surface of neutral Mo12O36/W12O36 cage can provide various sites to stabilize single Rh atom by combination of its surface oxygen atoms, which includes bride, three-fold hollow, and four-fold hollow sites, etc. Our previous works [66] and experimental results [65] both demonstrated that the single metal atom was located at four-fold hollow site of PTA/PMA supports. In the present paper, the Rh atom was also assigned at four-fold hollow site of Mo12O36/W12O36 cage in our optimization calculations, where the Rh atom coordinates to two Ob and Oc atoms to form the rectangular pyramid coordination sphere (see Fig. 1). From the viewpoint of clathrate structure, the interaction energy of Rh3+ and PMA/PTA anion (E tot) has been separated into electrostatic energy of Rh3+cation and PO4 3− anion (E es) and bonding energy for coordination of Rh3+ to neutral Mo12O36/W12O36 cage (E b). The calculated E tot, E b, and E es values have been compared in Fig. 1. We take the Rh1/PMA SAC as an example to probe these bonding natures. It can be found that the calculated E b and E es values of Rh1/PMA both are closed to -1 eV (E b = -1.27 and E es = -0.96 eV). The roughly same values of E b and E es indicate that coordination bonding and electrostatic attraction equally contributes to stabilizing of Rh atom onto the PMA surface. The interaction energy of the Rh3+ cation and PMA anion is calculated to be -2.23 eV according to our DFT calculations. In our previous investigation [66], we have demonstrated that the strong metal-support interaction weakens the W-Ob/Oc bonding interaction, and thus the surface Ob and Oc atoms, which are coordinated to the single metal atom, was effectively activated by the single metal atom. In the present paper, the key molecular geometries of Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA SACs have been compared in Fig. 2 . In order to reveal anchoring effects on the activation of surface Ob and Oc atoms of both POM supports, the free PTA and PMA anions both have been optimized at the same level in this work. A detailed comparison of PMA and Rh1/PMA shows that the optimized Mo–Ob distance increases from ~1.9 Å to ~2.1 Å, and Mo–Oc distance increases from ~1.9 Å to ~2.0 Å. Such elongation effects on the Mo–Ob and Mo–Oc distances lead to decreasing the bond angle of Mo–Ob–Mo from 152° to 147°, and Mo–Oc–Mo decrease from 125° to 119°. As shown in Fig. 2, the same result is found in Rh1/PTA. All these results indicate that the Ob and Oc atoms localized in different chemical environments and were pulled from the PMA surface to close the Rh atom. 3.2 CO adsorption According to Sabatier principle, the excellent catalysts should bind atoms and molecules with a moderate strength: not too weak so they can activate the reactants and not too strong so the products can desorb [78]. However, it is still a challenged task to sophisticatedly control the adsorption strength of catalysts. In the present paper, redox property of POM support was adopted to tune the adsorption behavior of both SACs for CO. It is well-known that the nature of frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) can provide qualitative insight into the redox properties. For the Keggin-type POMs, they all have the analogous nature of FMOs, where the occupied oxo-ligand 2p orbitals and the empty set of d-like metal orbitals are separated with large gap between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO), and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). According to previous study [79], the low d metal orbitals in PMA relevant to that of PTA effectively lower the energy level of LUMO. Thus, PMA are more powerful oxidizing agents than the corresponding PTA by ~0.5 eV. However, anchoring of Rh atom on both POM support significantly influences the distribution of FMOs. The FMO diagram obtained from the optimized structures of Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs using M06L functional are compared in Fig. 3 . It can be found that the five metal d orbitals of Rh atom were well inserted between occupied oxo-ligand 2p orbitals and the empty set of d-like metal orbitals of both POM supports. For Rh1/PMA SAC, the quintet degenerate d orbitals of free Rh atom completely split in the rectangular pyramid coordination sphere, which results in HOMO-2, HOMO-1, and HOMO are the dxy, dz2, and dxz-type orbitals, respectively. And the LUMO+1 and LUMO+5 of Rh1/PMA are dxz and dx2-y2-type orbital, respectively. By contrast, in Rh1/PTA SAC LUMO and LUMO+1 are dxz and dx2-y2-type orbitals, respectively. Such difference on unoccupied orbital distribution leads to the lower energy level of LUMO in Rh1/PTA SAC, and thus Rh1/PTA is stronger oxidant than Rh1/PMA. It is well-known that CO is the typical reductant, low-lying LUMO of Rh1/PTA is easier to accept electrons from CO molecule when compared with the Rh1/PMA SAC (see below). As a result, Rh1/PTA should possess a strong capacity to adsorb CO molecule. In order to test prediction from molecular orbital theory, the adsorption energies (E ad) of Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs for CO molecule both have been calculated by using our DFT calculations. And the calculated E ad values have been compared in Fig. 4 . Our previous study has demonstrated that the adsorption energy of CO is sensitive to the surface structure of POM-supported SAC [66]. As shown in Fig. 4, our DFT calculations well reproduce this trend, the calculated E ad value is closely associated with the nature of POM surfaces. Such as the calculated E ad value is -52.84 kcal/mol for the configuration (a) with adsorbed two CO molecules adjacent to Ob atom of PMA surface, which is more negative than that of the configuration (b) with adsorbed two CO molecules adjacent to Oc atom of PMA surface (-20.43 kcal mol–1). All these results indicate that the absolute value of E ad in Rh1/PTA is significantly larger than that of Rh1/PMA, which are well in agreement with the prediction of molecular orbital theory. Thus, redox property of SACs can effectively tune the adsorption behavior of CO over both POM-supported SACs. 3.3 Reaction mechanism According to previous reports in the literature [50, 65], the MvK mechanism of CO oxidation starts from oxidation of adsorbed CO by the surface oxygen atoms of POM support to form a key intermediate with an oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface. Because of the strong adsorption behavior, the configuration for adsorption of two CO molecules on Rh1/PMA SAC has been assigned as the reactant to carry out the MvK pathway. Meanwhile, the Ob and Oc atoms both have been considered to oxidize the adsorbed CO molecule because they are localized in different chemical environments. The calculated free energy profiles for the oxidation of the first CO molecule to form oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface via removal of Ob or Oc atom have been compared in Fig. 5 . It can be found that the calculated free energy barrier corresponding to oxidation the first CO molecule by the Ob atom is 21.26 kcal/mol. By contrast, the calculated free energy barrier relative to oxidation of the first CO molecule by the Oc atom is 35.49 kcal/mol. Meanwhile, our DFT calculations show that they have the same thermodynamic driving force for removal of Ob or Oc atom to form oxygen vacancy (-40.66 vs. -44.58 kcal/mol). These results indicate that the removal of the Ob atom is a thermodynamically favorable process with a low activation energy barrier of 21.26 kcal/mol, which is consistent with the experimentally estimated barrier of ~30 kcal/mol. Next, we examined the associative pathways about the replenishment of the Rh1/PMA SAC by the reaction of CO and O2. Our previous works [66] indicate that the O2 molecule was refilled into the oxygen vacancy with bonding interactionbetween O2 and the Rh atom. Because the Rh-O2 bonding interaction reduces the reactivity of the adsorbed O2 molecule, there is a high free energy barrier for the reaction of O2 and CO. In the present paper, the key intermediate, refilling of O2 molecule into the oxygen vacancy of Rh1/PMA, has been optimized in this work. The optimized geometries (*CO+*O2 ) have been listed in Fig. 6 . It can be found that the optimized Rh-O2 distance is 2.065 Å for Rh1/PMA, suggesting a bonding interaction between them. Thus, we believe that the adsorbed O2 molecule should have a low reactivity for oxidation of CO. As supported by our free energy calculations, the calculated free energy barrier is 41.15 kcal/mol (see Fig. 6, blue color) for oxidation of the second CO molecule by the adsorbed O2. Such high free energy barrier encourages us to consider an alternative pathway corresponding to oxidation of the second CO molecule by surface oxygen atom to form a new oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 6 (red color), starting from *CO+*O2 , adsorbed CO molecule reacts with the adjacent Oc atom to form the new oxygen vacancy via two transition states with the free energy barrier of 7.24 for TS3c and 12.60 kcal/mol for TS4c, which are significantly lower than that of oxidation CO by the adsorbed O2 molecule (41.15 kcal/mol), After desorption of the formed second CO2 molecule, the Oc atom was removed from the catalyst surface to form intermediate Rh-Ov,c-O2 with an oxygen vacancy. For the key intermediate Rh-Ov,c-O2 , the Rh atom is in the unsaturated state, and thus has the capability to adsorb additional CO molecule. Meanwhile, Rh-Ov,c-O2 can adsorb the second O2 molecule to refill the oxygen vacancy. However, our optimization calculations show that Rh-Ov,c-O2 cannot adsorb CO molecule in the presence of oxygen vacancy thermodynamically. By contrast, refilling of the second O2 molecules into the oxygen vacancy can form a stable intermediate *CO+2*O2 . This process is calculated to be exothermic by 26.75 kcal/mol. And *CO+2*O2 can easily adsorbe CO molecule to saturate the Rh atom and form 2*CO+2*O2 . This process is calculated to be slightly endothermic by 5.09 kcal/mol. Interestingly, our optimization calculations show that the conversion of *CO+2*O2 to 2*CO+2*O2 results in the formation of a key Mo-O6-O7-Mo unit with one O6-O7 distance of 1.389 Å and two Mo-O distances of 2.065 and 2.080 Å, respectively. And the optimized Rh-O2 distance is 2.112 and 2.912Å for O7 and O6 atoms of the adsorbed O2 molecules in 2*CO+2*O2 , indicating strong/weak bonding interaction of Rh atom and O7/O6 atom. Owing to O6 atom of the Mo-O6-O7-Mo unit does not bind the Rh atom, it may have the high reactivity for the oxidation of the third CO molecule to form CO2 molecule. The calculated free energy profile for the oxidation of the third CO molecule by the O6 atom of the Mo-O6-O7-Mo unit has been shown in Fig. 7 . The results show that it undergoes two transition states with the free energy barrier of 8.03 kcal/mol for TS5c and 13.44 kcal/mol for TS6c , respectively. Obviously, such low energy barrier mainly arises from the unique adsorbed configuration of O2. After desorption of the third CO2 molecule from the catalyst surface, the oxygen vacancy was replenished. In order to probe the support effects on the reaction mechanism, the free energy profile for CO oxidation catalyzed by the Rh1/PTA SAC also have been calculated at the same levels. The calculated reaction pathways along our proposed mechanism have been compared in Fig. 8 . It can be found that oxidation of the first CO molecule by the surface Ob atom needs to overcome the roughly same energy barrier for both SACs studied here (25.12 vs 21.26 kcal/mol). And extraction of the Ob atom from the PMA surface to form the oxygen vacancy and the first CO2 molecule results in a more stable intermediate relevant to that of PTA support, as supported by the calculated relative energy of -31.74 kcal/mol for Rh1/PMA and -21.73 kcal/mol for Rh1/PTA. In the oxidation of the second CO molecule, extraction of the Oc atom from the PMA surface to form CO2 need to undergo a relative high barrier when compared to that of PTA surface (12.60 vs. 7.99 kcal/mol). And desorption of the second CO2 molecule to form oxygen vacancy on the PMA surface results in a more stable intermediate relative to that of PTA surface (-49.30 vs -46.97 kcal/mol). Owing to this low relative energy, adsorbing of CO molecule to saturate the Rh atom need to overcome a thermodynamic barrier of 5.09 kcal/mol. By contrast, adsorbing of CO molecule to saturate the Rh atom on the PMA has very small thermodynamically barrier of 1.79 kcal/mol. Although much efforts have been made, we did not find the transition state corresponding to extraction of the second CO2 molecule from the PTA surface. In the oxidation of the third CO molecule, cleavage of adsorbed O2 to oxidize the third CO molecule needs to undergo two free energy barriers of 8.03 and 13.44 kcal/mol for Rh1/PMA, 8.67 and 12.08 kcal/mol for Rh1/PTA, respectively. Finally, the calculated reaction energies of -155.29 for Rh1/PTA and -161.23 kcal/mol for Rh1/PMA indicate the large thermodynamic driving force for the whole reaction. All these results indicate that the energy curve for Rh1/PMA system locates in the bottom and has the low activation barrier. A full reaction mechanism for the studied pathway about CO oxidation catalyzed by the Rh1/PMA or Rh1/PMA SAC has been summarized in the Fig. 9 . The first step is the oxidation of the first CO molecule by the Ob atom of the PMA/PTA surface to form the CO2 and an oxygen vacancy with a moderate free energy barrier of 21.26/25.12 kcal/mol. The next step is the adsorption of O2 and CO to refill the oxygen vacancy and saturate Rh center. Owing to the strong Rh-O2 bonding and very high free energy barrier, CO will be oxidized by the adsorbed O2 molecule difficultly. Alternatively, the second CO molecule was oxidized by the surface Oc atom of PMA/PTA support to form CO2 and a new oxygen vacancy with a relevant low free energy barrier of 12.60/7.99 kcal/mol. After refilling of O2 molecule into the new oxygen vacancy and adsorption of the third CO molecule to the Rh center, the key intermediate containing Mo-O-O-Mo unit was formed. Because one of the oxygen atoms in the Mo-O-O-Mo unit does not bind to the Rh atom, the third CO molecule can be easily oxidized by this O atom with a low barrier of 13.44/8.03 kcal/mol to form CO2. Finally, the unsaturated Rh atom adsorbs CO to complete the catalytic cycle. Meanwhile, such catalytic cycle indicates that intermediate *CO containing two adsorbed CO molecules does not directly take part in the catalytic cycle, and should be viewed as the catalyst precursor. 3.4 Oxidation state changes of the Rh center It has been found that the oxidation state changes of the Rh atom plays the key role for the whole reaction mechanism. Experimentally, reduction of Rh(III) to Rh(I) has been observed as oxidation of the first CO molecule via extraction of surface oxygen atom from the POM support to form CO2 and an oxygen vacancy. In the present paper, the atomic charge changes of the Rh center in Rh1/PMA and Rh1/PTA SACs along the favorable route have been compared in Fig. 10 . We employ the Rh1/PMA SAC as example to analyze the oxidation state changes of the Rh center. It can be found that adsorption of two CO molecules to the Rh(III) center significantly decrease of Rh atomic charge from +1.00 to +0.145, indicating two adsorbed CO molecules donate electrons to the Rh(III) center, and thus Rh(III) is reduced to Rh(I). Starting from *CO, the Rh atomic charge increases from +0.145 to +0.5 during the formation of first CO2 molecule, indicating Rh(I) center donates electrons to promote the formation of the new [CO]-[Ob] bond, and Rh(I) was oxidized to Rh(II). Next, the Rh atomic charge decreases from +0.5 to +0.2 as the formation of oxygen vacancy, indicating that the Rh(II) center accepts the extra electrons from the oxygen vacancy as extraction of the forming CO2 molecule from the oxygen vacancy. Finally, the atomic charge of the Rh(II) center decreases from +0.2 to -0.04 as adsorption of CO to the Rh center, indicating the Rh(II) center has been reduced to Rh(I). As shown in Fig. 10, starting from *CO@Ov,b, there are two stages of the Rh atom charge increases during the oxidation of the second CO molecule, which corresponds to the adsorption of two O2 molecule, indicating that the Rh(I) center was oxidized to Rh(II) by the adsorbed O2 molecules. After desorption of the second CO2 molecule and formation of the oxygen vacancy, oxidation of the third CO molecule by the adsorbed O2 molecule increases the Rh atomic charge from +0.208 to +0.504, indicating the Rh(I) center was oxidized to Rh(II) with the formation of the third CO2 molecule, this upward trend of the Rh atom charge indicates that Rh(I) center donates electrons to promote the cleavage of the O2 and formation of the new [CO]-[Ob] bond. All these results show that the three peak values of the Rh atomic charge in the whole reaction pathway suggest the formation of Rh(II) intermediate. These findings would be very useful to verify our proposed MvK mechanism for CO oxidation with the presence of the Rh(II) intermediate. 4 Conclusion In summary, we focused on POM-supported SACs containing single Rh sties on the unimolecular PTA and PMA supports. We investigated the reaction mechanism of CO oxidation by means of DFT-M06L calculations, which allowed us to precisely assign transition states and intermediates to provide a Rh-assisted MvK mechanism for CO oxidation, which involves the consecutive oxidation of three CO molecules over Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA SACs. The first CO molecule was oxidized by the surface O atom of POM support to form CO2 molecule and an oxygen vacancy. The surface oxygen vacancy was refilled by O2 molecule. For oxidation of the second CO molecule, similar to our previous study, it is difficult for the adsorbed O2 molecule because the bonding interaction between Rh atom and O2 molecule weakens the reactivity of the O2 molecule. Alternatively, the second CO molecule was easily oxidized by the surface O atom of PMA/PTA support to form the second CO2 molecule and a new oxygen vacancy, which was refilled by the O2 molecule to form key intermediate 2*CO+2*O2 containing Mo-O-O-Mo unit. Owing to one of oxygen atom in the Mo-O-O-Mo unit does not bind to the Rh atom, the third CO molecule can be easily oxidized by this O atom to form CO2 molecule. Compared with Rh1/PTA, the energy curve of Rh1/PMA locates in the bottom and has the low activation barrier in this Rh-assisted MvK mechanism. Therefore, Rh1/PMA SAC possesses a high reactivity for CO oxidation relevant to Rh1/PTA, which is well in agreement with the experimental results. The atomic charge analysis along the proposed MvK pathway shows that the oxidation state of the Rh center changes among III, II, and I, which promotes electron transfer and the whole reaction. coredata.dc:description: The low and insufficient anchored site on support structure is the bottleneck problem for development of single-atom catalysts (SACs). Owing to the discrete anionic structure, the surface structure of unimolecular polyoxometalates (POMs) in solid is more like the fragments of metal oxide and possesses the unique separate structure, which can be viewed as the separate small “island” and effectively prevent agglomeration of single metal atoms. In the present paper, the mechanism of CO oxidation by O2 was systematically studied over two POM-supported SACs, Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA (PTA = [PW12O40]3− and PMA = [PMo12O40]3−) by means of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The results indicated that this process involves consecutive oxidation of three CO molecules over Rh1/PTA and Rh1/PMA SACs via a Rh-assisted Mar-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. The first CO molecule was oxidized by a bridged O atom of POM support to form CO2 molecule and an oxygen vacancy. The surface oxygen vacancy was refilled by O2 molecule, and the second CO molecule was oxidized by a corner O atom of the POM support to form CO2 molecule and a new oxygen vacancy. Finally, the forming surface oxygen vacancy was replenished by the O2 molecule to form the key Mo-O-O-Mo unit, which can easily oxidize the third CO to form the CO2 molecule. Compared with the reported MvK mechanism, the significant difference arises from oxidation of the second CO molecule, in which the second CO molecule was oxidized by the corner O atom of the POM support rather than adsorbed O2 molecule. This is mainly due to a low reactivity for the adsorbed O2 molecule, which comes from a bonding interaction between the adsorbed O2 molecule and the single Rh atom. The atomic charge analysis show that the single Rh atom stabilized on the POM supports promotes the whole catalytic cycle via the change of oxidation state among III, II, and I. All these results show that the presence of single Rh atom on the unimolecular PTA and PMA supports is a key factor for determination of new reaction pathway and high reactivity. We hope our computation results can provide new physical insights to design SACs for CO oxidation by using unimolecular POM cluster. The reaction mechanism of CO oxidation by O2 was systematically studied over two polyoxometalate-supported single-atom catalysts by means of density functional theory calculations.
coredata.dc:title: Mars–van Krevelen mechanism for CO oxidation on the polyoxometalates-supported Rh single-atom catalysts: An insight from density functional theory calculations
